Topics.title: Overview
Topics.content: Orbipay Checkout© is a payment platform that merchants can use in order to accept payments from their customers who place orders on their websites. The payments can be accepted on a one-time basis from credit cards, debit cards or bank accounts.

subTopics.title: How Checkout works
subTopics.content:
1. Orbipay Checkout© is a Payment Solution Gateway Provider and has Public Key PK0 and Secret Key SK0. Any Partner/Merchant who want to offer payments related functionality using Checkout will be given a key pair per environment (PKi and Ski (2048 bits, Algorithm- RSA)).

  2. Orbipay Checkout© provides two libraries, a) Browser SDK and b) Client SDK

  3. Browser SDK needs to be imported on the payment page and the Client SDK has to be added as a dependency to the server side code.

  4. Browser SDK takes client Id and callback URL as input.

  5. Client SDK comes with a checkout_client.properties file for initial configurations.

  6. Client SDK also contains the key pair of that merchant in a java key store(Password protected) .

  7. Java key store (JKS) file password, key alias and Ski password are configurable in config.properties.

  8. Merchant’s web front-end posts the retrieve merchant to Checkout and get the response back as a pop up form if given client id id correct.

  9. Merchant’s web front-end posts the payment details to Orbipay Checkout© server(Encrypted with PK0)

  10. Orbipay Checkout© validates and generates Payment-Token and sends it back to the web front-end(Encrypted with PK1 and Signed by SK0).

  11. Web front-end posts the order details and the Payment-Token to the Merchant Server (Using Browser SDK).

  12. Merchant back-end server using Server SDK verifies the authenticity of the Payment-Token by decrypting it and submits it to Orbipay Checkout© for payment confirmation.

  13. Orbipay Checkout© processes the payment and sends Success/Failure response to Merchant back-end server.

  14. Merchant back-end server notifies the Order Success/Failure response to the web front-end.

Topics.title: Design Documents
Topics.content: The main objective is to present one of the integration approach where the customer stays on merchant website during the entire purchase process (i.e., does not get redirected to Orbipay’s site etc). All the work of payment capture process is done by Orbipay Checkout© behind-the-scenes. This approach to enable a merchant to accept payments is achieved through tokenization.

subTopics.title: Client On-boarding
subTopics.content:
Client On-boarding involves the following

• Registering with the Orbipay© platform

• Generating security keys (Public Key & Secret Key – for both Test and Live modes)

• Registering with Checkout application

• Download the Platform specific Server and Client SDKs

subTopics.title: Client Integration
subTopics.content:
Checkout provides browser/client SDK (front-end integration) and server SDK (back-end integration) for integration to Checkout. We support different ways to integrate, they are simple and custom. 

For securely collecting payment information without posting the customer’s payment information to client's server we use tokenization approach.

Tokenization:

With Checkout, sensitive customer’s payment information does not hit client's server, minimizing client's PCI compliance burden. Just enabling HTTPS on client's checkout/payment page is enough, and Checkout takes care of everything from there. 

How tokenization works with SSL encryption and digital signature:

  1. The customer arrives at payment page that includes the Checkout code, loaded over HTTPS.
  2. The customer clicks the payment button (e.g., Pay), completes the payment form, and clicks Pay in the Checkout window.
  3. Checkout sends the payment details directly to Checkout from the customer's browser, assuming the details pass basic validation.
  4. Checkout returns a encrypted(with client's public key) token and digital signature for the token generated with Checkout private key  to the payment page, or an error message if the funding account validation fails.
  5. Browser SDK posts the token and digiSign to client's server.
  6. Client's server decrypts the token with their private key and verifies the digiSign with Checkout public key.
  7. Again they encrypt the token with Checkout public key and  generate digiSign for the token with their private key.
  8.  Using Server SDK encrypted token and digiSign with other details are posted to Checkout for confirm payment.
  9. Checkout server decrypts the token with Checkout private key and verifies the digiSign with client's public key.
  10. Checkout responds back with success or failure and accordingly Client shows message to their customer.

Note: Steps 6,7 and 8 are taken care in Server SDK. Client does not need to worry about all these encryption/decryption and digiSign generation/verification. They just have to provide the same token and digiSign they receive.

Checkout supports three different ways of integration : 

  • Simple Integration:

    1. Iframe

    2. Simple Html Div Tag Integration

  • Custom Integration:
    1. Embedded Payment Form / Custom Integration

Website Integration involves the following development (By Client IT):

  • Front-End development for handling payment capture using Browser / ClientSDK
  • Back-End development for confirming the payment using ServerSDK

 

Front-End UI development:

 

  • Simple Integration:

    Simple Integration is the easiest way to integrate Checkout. In this approach payment form opens as a pop-up (Overlay) on the client's checkout/payment page. And a minimal java script inclusion on the payment page does the work.

    • Step 1:  Add a button/Input with id = “checkout-button”.

      <button id = "checkout-button">Pay</button>

    • Step 2:  Add the following script.

      <script id = "checkout-script"
           src = "https://www.orbipay.com/js/checkoutofsc.js"
           data-key = "cli_avmg585852kw555p""
           data-clienturl = "/onlineshopping/post-token"
           data-amount = "56"
           data-iframe = "true"
           data-chargerefno = "ord_82bad47fe43e7b8586ff672e8e6"
           data-customer_id = "cust_3e7b8586ff672e8" >
      </script>

      Where,

      • data-key is a unique identifier for a partner in Checkout.

      • data-clienturl is the URL to which token will be posted. The URL to be supplied by Merchant.

      • data-amount is amount to be charged.

      • data-iframe is to choose between iframe or div approach in simple integration, if 'true' then iframe else div.

      • data-chargerefno is unique order no. for a transaction.

      • data-customer_id is unique customer id maintained by merchant (optional).

 

  • Custom Integration:

    Custom integration allows to have complete control over the look and feel of your payment form and include the Checkout provided attributes for every input in the form. Your form can be customized however you need and the submitted funding source information is tokenized directly with Checkout. In this approach little more development is required on the payment page to give you more control.

    • Step 1:  Design payment form (However you design the form, just the exact value for the data-checkout attribute should be provided for each element).

      Bank Form:

      <form id="pmt-form-bank" action="/cameron-insurance/post-token" method="POST">
           <label>Name of Account Holder *</label><input data-checkout="nameonaccount" type="text">
           <label>Email *</label><input data-checkout="email-bank" type="text">
           <label>Account Number *</label><input data-checkout="acctno" type="text">
           <label>Confirm Account Number *</label><input data-checkout="confirmacctno" type="text">
           <label>Account Type *</label>
           <select data-checkout="acctType">
                <option value="checking">Checking</option>
                <option value="savings">Savings</option>
           </select>
           <label>Routing Number *</label><input data-checkout="routingNumber" type="text">
           <label>Address Line1 </label><input data-checkout="address-line1-bank" type="text">
           <label>Address Line2 </label><input data-checkout="address-line2-bank" type="text">
           <label>State </label>
           <select data-checkout="state-bank">
                <option value="">Select State</option>
                <option value="AL">Alabama</option>
                <option value="AK">Alaska</option>
                               .......................
           </select>
           <label>City </label><input data-checkout="city-bank">
           <label>Country </label>
           <select id="country-bank" class="form-control " data-checkout="country-bank">
                <option value="USA">USA</option>
           </select>
           <label>Zip </label><input data-checkout="zip1-bank" type="text"><input data-checkout="zip2-bank" type="text">
           <label>Phone Number </label><input data-checkout="phone-bank" type="tel">
           <input type="hidden" data-checkout="order-no-bank" value="" />
           <input type="submit" value="Pay"/>
       </form>

      Card Form:

      <form id="pmt-form-card" action="/cameron-insurance/post-token" method="POST">
           <label>Name On Card *</label><input data-checkout="name-on-card" type="text">
           <label>Card Number *</label><input data-checkout="card-number" type="text">
           <label>Expiry Date *</label><input data-checkout="exp-card" type="text">
           <label>CVV *</label><input data-checkout="cvv" type="text">
           <label>Email *</label><input data-checkout="email-card" type="text">
           <label>Address Line1 </label><input data-checkout="address-line1-card" type="text">
           <label>Address Line2 </label><input data-checkout="address-line2-card" type="text">
           <label>State </label>
           <select data-checkout="state-card">
                <option value="">Select State</option>
                <option value="AL">Alabama</option>
                <option value="AK">Alaska</option>
                               .......................
           </select>
           <label>City </label><input data-checkout="city-card">
           <label>Country </label>
           <select id="country-bank" class="form-control " data-checkout="country-card">
                <option value="USA">USA</option>
           </select>
           <label>Zip </label><input data-checkout="zip1-card" type="text"><input data-checkout="zip2-card" type="text">
           <label>Phone Number </label><input data-checkout="phone-card" type="tel">
           <input type="hidden" data-checkout="order-no-card" value="" />
           <input type="submit" value="Pay"/>
       </form>

      Note: Mandatory fields has '*' in the label name.

      Validation helpers:

      • OrbipayCheckout.bank.validateRoutingNumber(routingNo);
      • OrbipayCheckout.bank.validateAccountNumber(acctNo);
      • OrbipayCheckout.card.validateCardNumber(cardNo);
      • OrbipayCheckout.card.validateExpiry(exp);
      • OrbipayCheckout.card.validateCVC(cvc);
      • OrbipayCheckout.card.cardType(cardNo);

    • Step 2:  Include the following script.

       <script id = "checkout-script" src="https://www.orbipay.com/js/checkoutofsc.js"</script>

       

    • Step 3:  Provide ClientId, ExtCustomerId and Amount.

      OrbipayCheckout.setClientId("cli_avmg585852kw555p");
      OrbipayCheckout.setExtCustomerId("cust_3e7b8586ff672e8"); // optional
      OrbipayCheckout.setAmount("56");

       

    • Step 4:  Collect customer’s payment information.

      • Bank Payment:

        $formBank.submit(function(event) {
             try {
                // Disable the submit button to prevent repeated clicks:
                $formBank.find('.submit').prop('disabled', true);
                // Request a token from OrbipayCheckout:
                OrbipayCheckout.bank.createToken($formBank, checkoutResponseHandler);
                // Prevent the form from being submitted:
                return false;
             }catch(err){
                console.log(err);
                return false;   // Prevent the form from being submitted:
             }
        });

         

      • Card Payment:

        $formCard.submit(function(event) {
             try {
                // Disable the submit button to prevent repeated clicks:
                $formCard.find('.submit').prop('disabled', true);
                // Request a token from OrbipayCheckout:
                OrbipayCheckout.card.createToken($formCard, checkoutResponseHandler);
                // Prevent the form from being submitted:
                return false;
             }catch(err){
                console.log(err);
                return false;   // Prevent the form from being submitted:
             } 
        });

         

    • Step 5:  Handle the response and post the token to merchant server with the following additional form parameters.

      function checkoutResponseHandler(status, response) {
           // Grab the form
           var $formBank = $('#pmt-form-bank');
           var $formCard = $('#pmt-form-card');

       

           if (status === false) { // Problem!
                // Show the errors on the form
                $('#payment-errors').text(response.error);
                $('#payment-errors').prop('hidden', false);
                $formBank.find('.submit').prop('disabled', false); // Re-enable submission
                $formCard.find('.submit').prop('disabled', false); // Re-enable submission
           } else { // Token was created!
                // Get the token ID
                $('#payment-errors').prop('hidden', true);
                if(response.chargeType === "bank"){
                     // Insert the token ID into the form so it gets submitted to the server
                     $formBank.append($('<input type="hidden" name="token">').val(response.token));
                     $formBank.append($('<input type="hidden" name="digiSign">').val(response.digiSign));
                     $formBank.append($('<input type="hidden" name="ext_cust_id">').val(response.ext_cust_id));
                     // Submit the form
                     $formBank.get(0).submit();
                }else if(response.chargeType === "card"){
                     // Insert the token ID into the form so it gets submitted to the server
                     $formCard.append($('<input type="hidden" name="token">').val(response.token));
                     $formCard.append($('<input type="hidden" name="digiSign">').val(response.digiSign));
                     $formCard.append($('<input type="hidden" name="ext_cust_id">').val(response.ext_cust_id));
                     // Submit the form
                     $formCard.get(0).submit();
                }
           }
      };

      Where,

      • token - Checkout generated token for the confirmation of payment. It can be used only once and comes with a expiry time.

      • digiSign - SSL digital signature for token generated with checkout private key.

      • ext_cust_id - Customer unique id maintained by merchant(optional).

     

Back-End development:

For processing the payment there is a minimal amount of programming required on the server side as well after adding server SDK as dependency. When the Order details along with the payment Token gets submitted to the Merchant Server. Checkout Server SDK takes care of following things:

  1. Decrypts the token and verifies the digital signature.

  2. Again encrypts the token with the checkout public key and signs with merchant private key.

  3. Submits the encrypted token and generated digital signature to checkout server for confirm charge request.

  4. Handles the response.

  • Confirm Charge Request:

    Checkout.init(CHECKOUT_CLIENT_ID, CLIENT_SIG_KEY);
    PaymentRequest paymentRequest = new PaymentRequest();
         paymentRequest.setAmount(amount);
         paymentRequest.setChargeTraceRefNo(chargeTraceRefNo);
         paymentRequest.setTokenId(token);
         paymentRequest.setDigiSign(digiSign);
    CheckoutResponse<Payment> checkoutResponse = CheckoutPayment.confirmCharge(paymentRequest);

 
  • Other Services we support using server SDK:
    •  Customer
      • Create Customer Request:

        Checkout.init(CHECKOUT_CLIENT_ID, CLIENT_SIG_KEY);
        CustomerRequest customerRequest = new CustomerRequest();
             customerRequest.setSourceType("token");
             Customer customer = new Customer();
                  customer.setCustomerId("user_examplecfhd88609");
                  customer.setEmail("willsmith@example.com");
                  customer.setFirstName("Will");
             customerRequest.setCustomer(customer);
             FundingAccount fundingAccount = new FundingAccount();
                  fundingAccount.setAccountHolderName("Will Smith");
                  fundingAccount.setAccountNumber("4124939999999990");
                  fundingAccount.setAccountType("card");
                  fundingAccount.setAccountSubtype("visa");
                  fundingAccount.setCardCvvNumber("123");
                  fundingAccount.setCurrencyCode3d("USD");
                  fundingAccount.setExpiryDate("11/29");
             customerRequest.setFundingAccount(fundingAccount);
        CheckoutResponse<CreateCustomerResponse> checkoutResponse = CheckoutCustomer.create(customerRequest);


    • Funding Account

      • Retrieve Customer’s Funding Accounts Request:

        Checkout.init(CHECKOUT_CLIENT_ID, CLIENT_SIG_KEY);
        RetrieveCustomerFundingAccountsRequest fundingAccountsRequest = new RetrieveCustomerFundingAccountsRequest();
             fundingAccountsRequest.setCustomerId("sai.123@gmail.com");
        CheckoutResponse<RetrieveCustomerFundingAccountsResponse> checkoutResponse = CheckoutFundingAccount.retrieveCustomerFundingAccounts(fundingAccountsRequest);

         

      • Get Customer’s Funding Accounts Page Request:

        Checkout.init(CHECKOUT_CLIENT_ID, CLIENT_SIG_KEY);
        GetFundingAccountsRequest fundingAccountsRequest = new GetFundingAccountsRequest();
             fundingAccountsRequest.setCustomerId("user_examplecfhd88609");
             fundingAccountsRequest.setQueryId("10");
             fundingAccountsRequest.setFrom("11");
             fundingAccountsRequest.setTo("15");
        CheckoutResponse<RetrieveCustomerFundingAccountsResponse> checkoutResponse = CheckoutFundingAccount.getCustomerFundingAccounts(fundingAccountsRequest);

         

      • Retrieve Funding Account Details Request:

        Checkout.init(CHECKOUT_CLIENT_ID, CLIENT_SIG_KEY);
        RetrieveFundingAccountsDetailsRequest fundingSourceDetailsRequest = new RetrieveFundingAccountsDetailsRequest();
             fundingSourceDetailsRequest.setFundingAccountId(fundingSourceId);
        CheckoutResponse<CustomerFundingAccountConsolidatedResponseRetrieve> checkoutResponse = CheckoutFundingAccount.retrieveFundingAccountDetails(fundingSourceDetailsRequest);

         

      • Delete Funding Account Request:

        Checkout.init(CHECKOUT_CLIENT_ID, CLIENT_SIG_KEY);
        DeleteFundingAccountRequest deleteFundingAccountRequest = new DeleteFundingAccountRequest();
             deleteFundingAccountRequest.setFundingAccountId(fundingAccountId);
        CheckoutResponse<DeleteFundingAccountResponse> checkoutResponse = CheckoutFundingAccount.deleteFundingAccount(deleteFundingAccountRequest);

         

    • Payment
      • Retrieve Customer’s Payments Request:

        Checkout.init(CHECKOUT_CLIENT_ID, CLIENT_SIG_KEY);
        RetrieveCustomerPaymentsRequest customerPaymentsRequest = new RetrieveCustomerPaymentsRequest();
             customerPaymentsRequest.setCustomerId("user_3746ythcfhd88609");
             customerPaymentsRequest.setInitialRecords("10");
             RetrievePaymentsRequest paymentsFilter = new RetrievePaymentsRequest();
                  paymentsFilter.setConfirmationId("GCC29QR24N");
                  paymentsFilter.setPaymentStatus("scheduled");
                  paymentsFilter.setFromDate("13/02/2017");
                  paymentsFilter.setToDate("20/02/2017");
             customerPaymentsRequest.setPaymentsRequest(paymentsFilter);
        CheckoutResponse<RetrieveCustomerPaymentsResponse> checkoutResponse = CheckoutPayment.retrieveCustomerPayments(customerPaymentsRequest);


         

      • Get Customer’s Payments Page Request:

        Checkout.init(CHECKOUT_CLIENT_ID, CLIENT_SIG_KEY);
        GetCustomerPaymentsRequest paymentsPageRequest = new GetCustomerPaymentsRequest();
             paymentsPageRequest.setCustomerId("user_examplecfhd88609");
             paymentsPageRequest.setQueryId("10");
             paymentsPageRequest.setFrom("11");
             paymentsPageRequest.setTo("15");
        CheckoutResponse<RetrieveCustomerPaymentsResponse> checkoutResponse = CheckoutPayment.getCustomerPayments(paymentsPageRequest);

         

      • Retrieve Payment Details Request:

        Checkout.init(CHECKOUT_CLIENT_ID, CLIENT_SIG_KEY);
        RetrievePaymentDetailsRequest paymentDetailsRequest = new RetrievePaymentDetailsRequest();
             paymentDetailsRequest.setPaymentId(paymentId);
        CheckoutResponse<CustomerPaymentConsolidatedResponseRetrieve> checkoutResponse = CheckoutPayment.retrievePaymentDetails(paymentDetailsRequest);

         

      • Cancel Payment Request:

        Checkout.init(CHECKOUT_CLIENT_ID, CLIENT_SIG_KEY);
        CancelPaymentRequest cancelPaymentRequest = new CancelPaymentRequest();
             cancelPaymentRequest.setPaymentId(paymentId);
        CheckoutResponse<CancelPaymentResponse> checkoutResponse = CheckoutPayment.cancelPayment(cancelPaymentRequest);

Topics.title: Security
Topics.content:
Go through the GRC confluence page to understand the security posture of Orbipay Checkout feature.

 

CheckOut Merchant Compliance Obligation

 

Checkout Sensitive Data Elements

subTopics.title: 2017 - Jun
subTopics.content:
Technical team Bank of America conducted ADSF Scan on checkout application and raised the findings as mentioned below. Though Priority 4 findings should be resolved but utmost priority is to be given for Priority 2 & 3. In total 6 findings, out of which 1 finding is Priority-2 and 4 findings of Priority-3 and one finding is of Priority-4. For Priority 2 findings security patches / fixes must be deployed within 45 calendar days from date of GIS Advisory notification wherein for Priority 3 findings  security patches / fixes must be deployed within 100 calendar days

July 12, 2017

After the call with BofA ADSF team the findings were reduced to three priority -3 findings.

July 17, 2017

BofA ADSF Team confirmed that they cannot downgrade the priority for finding 4, that left us with three priority - 3 findings. We should respond back to BofA with remediation plan and dates for 'ready for testing' as well as production dates. The fixes for the three findings should be in production before October 15, 2017. Please refer to the updated report attached below:

PDF

Priority
Count
Finding
2 1 Unauthorized Data access exists
3

4

3

1) Cookies not marked secure

2) Cross Frame scripting / Clickjacking

3) HTTP Methods are enabled

4) Unsafe CORS Policy
4 1 Cookie security: HTTPonly not set

 

Finding: 1

Priority: 2

Issue: Unauthorized Data Access Exists (Vertical Escalation)

Vulnerability Finding:

The application fails to perform permission checks for the user requesting the operation,allowing for lower privileged users to access and use features intended only for higher privileged accounts. Permissions
are checked when menu items are rendered, but a user can forcefully browse to other URL's in the application that they are not permitted to perform. If a user knows or can guess the URL to perform a privileged function, they can browse directly to the URL and they'll be given access to perform the action.

The application sets a JSESSIONID cookie but this cookie is never required for access to the payment functionality. There is no effective session tracking or authentication for the payment checkout. The client_id header is required for checkout and this value can be obtained when browsing to one of the three options for payment.

Affected URL:

https://sbjsco.billerpayments.com

Remediation:

Checkout host do not need any cookie and/or JSESSIONID as such, the cookie added on the simulation site (simjsco.billerpayments.com) is to demonstrate the features that Checkout Application supports.Hence we are not making any changes at application for this issue.

Implementation:Not Required

This finding is knocked off after discussion with ADSF Team

 

Finding: 2

Priority: 3

Issue: Cookies not marked secure

Vulnerability Finding:

The application did not configure cookies containing sensitive information with the secure flag. Cookies configured without the secure flag may be transmitted over a plaintext HTTP connection and subject to capture by 3rd parties. Even if the site doesn't employ plaintext HTTP connections, future changes in site design or accidental mis-configuration could enable HTTP traffic, expose these cookies and lead to session hijacking.

Affected URL:

https://sbjsco.billerpayments.com

Remediation:

Same as Finding #1, Checkout do not maintain and require any session, its one time payment that checkout capture's payment details and submit to Orbipay payment gateway. 

Implementation: Not Required

This finding is knocked off after discussion with ADSF Team


Finding: 3

Priority: 3

Issue: Cross Frame Scripting/Clickjacking (External)

Vulnerability Finding:

The application html code is able to be encapsulated within a frameset. Websites that are vulnerable to being encapsulated within a frameset are susceptible to a variety of vulnerabilities including but not limited to cross frame scripting), User Interface Redress Attack (a.k.a. clickjacking), etc.

Affected URL:

https://sbjsco.billerpayments.com/app/opco/v1/public/service/accounts/cli_avvb5p5b5pk55555?IFRAME=true

Remediation:

We would be adding X-FRAME-Options header directive with the client / partner domain name setup / stored at Checkout application. In addition to that we would be implementing frame-busting logic in the application as suggested by ADSF testing.

Implementation:

As part of partner on-boarding process and setup, we would be requesting all the domain names that the partner will be presented / integrate for the customer and the same would be setup against the partner. If the client is opted for IFRAME integration option we would be sending X-FRAME-OPTIONS Allow-From XXX directive domemain name  / URL as that of partner shared during the on-boarding process. By default will set it as DENY.

We should submit remediation action plan by 7/17/2017 . The action plan must include estimated testing dates and estimated production dates.


Finding: 4

Priority: 3

Issue: HTTP Methods are Enabled

Vulnerability Finding:

HTTP methods (WebDAV) are enabled on the server, potentially allowing users to remotely alter or delete content on the web server. The server reported that the following commands were accepted: GET; HEAD; POST; PUT; DELETE; TRACE; OPTIONS; MOVE; INDEX; MKDIR; RMDIR.

Affected URL:

https://sbjsco.billerpayments.com/

Remediation:

 

Implementation:

We should submit remediation action plan by 7/17/2017 . The action plan must include estimated testing dates and estimated production dates.

 


Finding: 5

Priority: 3

Issue: Unsafe CORS Policy

Vulnerability Finding:

The application used an unrestricted or inappropriate Cross-Origin Resource Policy. A CORS policy defines what other domains may interact with the application in a way that would allow users who visit an allowed domain to have content from the application stolen or for the allowed domain to carry out actions in the application in the context of the authenticated user.

Affected URL:

https://sbjsco.billerpayments.com/

Remediation:

The issue is similar to Finding #3 above, here the issue related to Access-Control-Allow-Origin HTTP header directive. Currently we set '*' for all the response instead of actual partner domain name.

Implementation:

The implementation would be similar for Finding #3 the difference is that its applicable for all checkout integration options and checkout app would be formatting Access-Control-Allow-Origin  HTTP header directive with the partner domain name stored in db.

We should submit remediation action plan by 7/17/2017 . The action plan must include estimated testing dates and estimated production dates.


Finding: 6

Priority: 4

Issue: Cookie Security: HTTPOnly not Set

Vulnerability Finding:

If the HttpOnly attribute is set on  a cookie then the cookies value cannot be read or set by clientside JavaScript. This measure can prevent certain client-side attacks such as cross-site scripting from trivially capturing the cookies value via an injected script.

Affected URL:

https://sbjsco.billerpayments.com/

Remediation:

Similar to Finding #1 & #2, Checkout doesn't maintain any session for the user who is making the payment. Please refer the Finding #1 & #2.

This finding is knocked off after discussion with ADSF Team

subTopics.title: Client Onboarding
subTopics.content:
Client On-boarding involves the following steps needs to be done for any clients to start integrate and test the checkout feature.

1. Registering with the Orbipay Platform (OBP) to accept payments via Checkout Channel

2. Generating secure keys (Public Key & Secret Key)

3. Registering with Orbipay Checkout Application

4. Download the Platform specific Browser and Server SDKs

 

Onboarding Detailed steps explained : 

 

  1. Registering with the Orbipay Platform (OBP) to accept payments via Checkout Channel 
    1. Setting up the client on OBP system would be done with existing procedures 
    2. Checkout channel is enabled for the client on OBP system
    3. Have the following information is available after the client setup in OBP system

      1. Client Business Name : Full business name of the client

      2. Oribpay Issued Partner Key : OBP system issued partner key for the client
      3. Orbipay Issued Signature Key1 : OBP system generated signature key1
      4. Orbipay Issued Signature Key2 : OBP system generated signature key2
      5. Client Business Logo Name : Exact name of the client logo uploaded as part of OBP setup part of #a
      6. Payment Option : Client accept payments from bank, card or both, value should be one of the options listed below.
        • 1 - bank
        • 2 - card
        • 3 - both bank & card (Default)
      7. Address Capture : Address to be captured only for card or both this depending on the field #vi, value would be
        • 1 - card
        • 2 - both bank & card (Default)
      8. Payment Form Layout : Applicable to only IFrame & Simple Div Tag integration options. Currently checkout has two UI designs layouts
        • 1 - single column view of payment form elements (Default)
        • 2 - two column view of payment form elements
      9. Customer UID Type : Customer unique identification in Checkout, we have two options 

        • 1 - email (Client does not maintain customer base. Only offers payments from, in which checkout considers email id as unique)(Default)

        • 2 - ext_customer_id (Client maintains customer base and will share customer unique ids maintained by client to Checkout application)

  2. Generating secure keys (Public Key & Secret Key)

    There are two options to generate keystorey using keytool command depending on the client request
    1. Checkout system generates both Public & Private key pair - The case where client do not have an existing key pairs
      1. Generate a private key with OBP issued parther key as alias
        • keytool -genkey -v -keystore <Client_Keystore_File>.keystore -alias <ObpIssuedPartnerKey> -keyalg RSA -keysize 2048 -validity <noOfDays>
      2. Export client public certificate from the keystore (<Client_Keystore_File>.keystore)
        • keytool -export -alias <ObpIssuedPartnerKey>  -file <ObpIssuedPartnerKey>_pub.cer -keystore  <Client_Keystore_File>.keystore 
      3. Import CheckOut public key on to Client keystore
        • keytool -import -alias <Checkout_Public_Key_Alias> -file <Checkout_Public_Key>_pub.cer -keystore <Client_Keystore_File>.keystore
      4. Import Client public key on to Checkout keystore
        • keytool -import -alias <ObpIssuedPartnerKey> -file <ObpIssuedPartnerKey>_pub.cer -keystore <Checkout_Master_Keystore_File>.keystore

    2. Checkout system imports client public key & Share chcekout public key - The case where client shares their existing public key to us
      1. Import Client public key on to Checkout keystore
        • keytool -import -alias <ObpIssuedPartnerKey> -file <Client_Public_Key_File>.cer -keystore <Checkout_Master_Keystore_File>.keystore

  3. Registering with Orbipay Checkout Application

    1. Setup client on checkout systems using the utility program and with the following formatted information with comma separated

        Client Business Name Oribpay Issued Partner Key Orbipay Issued Signature Key1 Orbipay Issued Signature Key2 Client Business Logo Name Payment Option Address Capture Payment Form Layout Customer UID Type
      Eg. E-Shopper 3781546391 W94YRRPWCJ21VPQF W94YRRPWCJ21VPQF e-shopper.png 3 3 1 1

       

    2. Checkout system generated client_id for the OBP system partner key can be found in the same directory where the utility application running (file_name : merchants.txt)

        OBP_PARTNER_KEY CHECKOUT_ISSUED_CLIENT_ID
      Eg 3781546391 cli_avvb5p5b5d468883




  4. Download the Platform specific Browser and Server SDKs
